instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm working on a pesky <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had light liquid damage near the SMC. Replaced the nasty resistors/caps (isolated to the 3v42 areas near top of SMC), and got green light, but no fan. Tracked backwards and found that <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is pulsing quickly at low voltage (flipping from low-voltage to OL on multimeter quickly). My <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is present (3.4v) and steady, but since <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> was pulsing, I replaced the SMC, but no change. Still pulsing. I replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> just to make sure it wasn't causing issues, and no change--still pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

I also have fluctuating/pulsing readings for rails further down, but it all starts back at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. 

Not sure how to proceed; any ideas? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey Duke, ppbus is stable at 8.6v, yes. No shorts on 3v42 or pbus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pulsing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Must be corrosion somewhere else too. Check all rails for shorts, also check the usual <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and clock chip.
